docs.abstract: Editorial says while NATO bombing of Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Serbia, was terrible event, China's violent, stage-managed demonstrations outside US Embassy in Beijing was unwarranted, suggesting that improved relations between both countries have rested on dangerously unstable foundation; says given offensive nature of Chinese behavior, including efforts to steal nuclear secrets, Pres Clinton should proceed with caution, as well as determination to protect US interests, as he tries to repair relations (M)
docs.snippet: As if the war in Yugoslavia were not complicated enough, President Clinton must now deal with an infuriated China as he tries to fashion a political settlement in the Balkans. That is just one of several serious problems facing Mr. Clinton in the aft
docs.lead_paragraph: As if the war in Yugoslavia were not complicated enough, President Clinton must now deal with an infuriated China as he tries to fashion a political settlement in the Balkans. That is just one of several serious problems facing Mr. Clinton in the aftermath of last week's mistaken bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade. Another is China itself, which showed an ominously volatile side in its response to the accidental attack. In his six years as President, Mr. Clinton has not faced a more difficult set of foreign policy challenges. Only a few days ago, China seemed likely to go along with whatever peace plan Russia and the United States brought to the United Nations Security Council, where Beijing has a veto. Despite accusations of Chinese espionage at American nuclear weapons labs and Chinese efforts to influence the 1996 elections with improper campaign contributions, relations with Beijing seemed stable after last month's visit here by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji.

docs.abstract: Luis R Perez letter, commenting on Robert Kagan's May 11 Op-Ed on anti-American protests in Beijing over NATO's accidental bombing of China's Embassy in Belgrade, Serbia, deplores 'institutionalized appeasement' of China by US (S)

headline.main: On China, Time To Face Reality

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''China's No. 1 Enemy'' (Op-Ed, May 11): Yes, the accidental bombing of China's Belgrade embassy was a tragic error. Yes, it is a disgrace that our top intelligence agency could be so arrogant. However, the true disgrace lies in
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''China's No. 1 Enemy'' (Op-Ed, May 11): Yes, the accidental bombing of China's Belgrade embassy was a tragic error. Yes, it is a disgrace that our top intelligence agency could be so arrogant. However, the true disgrace lies in our institutionalized appeasement of China.

docs.abstract: Donald Sheff letter disputes Robert Kagan's May 11 Op-Ed article on anti-American demonstrations in Beijing protesting NATO bombing of Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Serbia (S)

headline.main: On China, Time To Face Reality

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Robert Kagan (Op-Ed, May 11) suggests and then dismisses a major cause of the Government-sponsored demonstrations in Beijing -- namely, the impending 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Robert Kagan (Op-Ed, May 11) suggests and then dismisses a major cause of the Government-sponsored demonstrations in Beijing -- namely, the impending 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

docs.abstract: Williams Safire Op-Ed column says it is America, not China, that is owed an apology now that China has falsely accused US of kililng Chinese in Belgrade embassy bombing, and encouraged trashing of US embassy in Beijing; says Chinese leaders are milking US bombing error to divert Chinese public attention on tenth anniversary of Tiananmen Square massare, to water down Congressional probe of their nuclear spying and to cancel human rights talks while extracting new trade concessions (M)
docs.snippet: After a week of whipping up hatred of Americans by accusing us of deliberately murdering Chinese journalists in Belgrade, President Jiang Zemin deigned to accept a call from The Great Apologizer.    For the fifth time, President Clinton apologized, e
docs.lead_paragraph: After a week of whipping up hatred of Americans by accusing us of deliberately murdering Chinese journalists in Belgrade, President Jiang Zemin deigned to accept a call from The Great Apologizer. For the fifth time, President Clinton apologized, expressed regrets, sent condolences, kowtowed and groveled, begging to be believed that we did not bomb China's embassy on purpose.

docs.abstract: News analysis of impact of nationalistic anti-American demonstrations in Beijing over NATO bombing of Chinese Embassy in Beijing; Chinese liberals and political dissidents foresee more immediate hard-line attitudes from country's leaders, but hope outburst of activism will galvanize generation forced to keep quiet for past 10 years (M)
docs.snippet: DIPLOMACY  * A 15-member United Nations team arrived in Belgrade en route to Kosovo on a mission that will be the body's first direct look at Kosovo since NATO's air war began.
docs.lead_paragraph: DIPLOMACY * A 15-member United Nations team arrived in Belgrade en route to Kosovo on a mission that will be the body's first direct look at Kosovo since NATO's air war began.

docs.abstract: Public anger percolates in Beijing over NATO bombing of Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, even though both Chinese and American officials show signs that height of crisis has passed; US Amb James Sasser says relationship between both countries is not permanently damaged and can be repaired over time; comments by Chinese officials and in Chinese media noted; photo (M)

headline.main: Public Anger Against U.S. Still Simmers In Beijing

docs.snippet: Anger continued to percolate here today over the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, even as both Chinese and American officials gave signs that the height of the crisis had passed.    On Saturday, the Chinese newspapers all carried fron
docs.lead_paragraph: Anger continued to percolate here today over the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, even as both Chinese and American officials gave signs that the height of the crisis had passed. On Saturday, the Chinese newspapers all carried front-page articles about President Clinton's Friday night phone call to President Jiang Zemin, who had refused to accept earlier calls from Mr. Clinton since the bombing. And today, the People's Daily featured stories about the need to strengthen China, rather than about American ''imperialism.''

docs.abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says stoning of US Embassy in Beijing, in retaliation for NATO's bombing of China's Belgrade embassy, was not organized entirely by Beijing Government; says America today inspires envy and resentment in Chinese youths, but also admiration; says Chinese leaders weighed how far to milk embassy stoning--before it threatened trade, tourism, investment and other relations; notes that four days was their limit; says United States must adopt equally multi-dimensional view in dealing with China, or it will revert to one-dimensional place (M)
docs.snippet: So I'm listening to the radio last week reporting on the stoning of the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, in retaliation for NATO's bombing of China's Belgrade embassy. But I can't help chuckling at the last line of the news report. It quotes China's Minister
docs.lead_paragraph: So I'm listening to the radio last week reporting on the stoning of the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, in retaliation for NATO's bombing of China's Belgrade embassy. But I can't help chuckling at the last line of the news report. It quotes China's Minister of Tourism as saying that despite the rock-throwing, China is perfectly safe and American and other tourists shouldn't think of staying away. Translation: We burn U.S. flags, not U.S. dollars. The anti-China crowd wants us to believe that the embassy stoning was organized entirely by the Beijing Government and shows the real, true, unchanging character of China. I beg to differ. What it shows us is the real, true, constantly evolving, multi-dimensional character of China, where government control is not what it used to be.

docs.abstract: Many Chinese in Beijing are angry with US over bombing of Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and find it hard to believe that it was mistake, but they cannot imagine China getting by without US; say there are so many different types of interactions now: economic, cultural and educational; political relations between China and US have entered tense new phase, battered by China's outrage over attack on its embassy and by Congressional committee's charge of extensive Chinese military espionage; even as geopolitics and prospect of strategic rivalry drive two countries apart, millions of personal and business relationships form thick social glue that binds them together; photo (M)

headline.main: On Unofficial Level, at Least, Chinese Value Ties to the U.S.

docs.snippet: One recent afternoon, as the Chinese press continued to rage against ''American imperialism,'' a 36-year-old lawyer named Wang darted from the newly opened Starbucks back into the law conference he was attending -- in place of an American delegate wh

byline.original: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL and ERIK ECKHOLM

docs.lead_paragraph: One recent afternoon, as the Chinese press continued to rage against ''American imperialism,'' a 36-year-old lawyer named Wang darted from the newly opened Starbucks back into the law conference he was attending -- in place of an American delegate who felt uneasy about traveling to Beijing. Mr. Wang, who wears cartoon neckties and loafers, went to college in Portland, Ore. At his Chinese law firm he works closely with American clients, and he still keeps in touch with dozens of friends in the United States.

docs.abstract: Top leaders of China's democracy movement gather at Harvard University for first time since soldiers drove them at gunpoint from Beijing's Tiananmen Square 10 years ago; gathering is itself significant since some of them spent years in prison and others have squabbled among themselves over what went wrong and what they can do from exile to change China's Government; among those who attend conference are Li Lu, Wang Dan and Shen Tong; photo (M)

headline.main: Exiled Leaders of Tiananmen Gather to Mull Errors and Accomplishments

docs.snippet: For the first time since soldiers drove them at gunpoint from Beijing's Tiananmen Square 10 years ago, the top leaders of China's democracy movement gathered at Harvard University today, like alumni converging for a reunion on the leafy New England c
docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since soldiers drove them at gunpoint from Beijing's Tiananmen Square 10 years ago, the top leaders of China's democracy movement gathered at Harvard University today, like alumni converging for a reunion on the leafy New England campus. The gathering of the men and women the Chinese Communists had denounced as instigators of a ''counter-revolutionary rebellion'' was itself significant, the leaders said, since some of them spent years in prison and others have squabbled among themselves over what went wrong and what they can do from exile to change China's Government.

docs.abstract: Number of people killed in Tiananmen Square crackdown on June 3-4, 1989 remains mystery; authorities have never made public full accounting of dead and injured, and they have stymied outside efforts to do so with campaign of silence; estimates of dead range from several hundred to over 2,000 (M)

headline.main: The Persistent Mystery: How Many Died in 1989?

docs.snippet: It remains a mystery to this day: How many people were killed in the crackdown near Tiananmen Square on the night of June 3-4, 1989?    The massacre is widely considered China's most significant political event in a generation, an event that people s
docs.lead_paragraph: It remains a mystery to this day: How many people were killed in the crackdown near Tiananmen Square on the night of June 3-4, 1989? The massacre is widely considered China's most significant political event in a generation, an event that people still discuss 10 years later. Yet there is a gaping hole in every conversation that touches on the protests. Just how bad was it?
